data.text: Restricted to the service of one employer, as a laborer hired by him for the year; as, “a numerous body of confined labourers,”
Restrained within limits; imprisoned; secluded; close; narrow; mean: as, a confined mind.
In pathology, constipated: as, the bowels may be confined.
having movement restricted to within a certain area; -- usually a building. Opposite of <ant>unconfined</ant>.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: deprived of liberty; especially placed under arrest or restraint.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: having movement restricted to within an enclosed outdoor area; -- of animals.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: having movement or progress restricted to a certain area.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
examples: an outbreak of the plague <ex>confined</ex> to one quarter of the city; wildfires <ex>confined</ex> to within the canyon

data.text: Simple past tense and past participle of <xref>confine</xref>.
